notes.text: Outside of tends to be more commonly used in the US than in Britain, where outside usually suffices, but, like its cousin off of, it is colloquial and not recommended for formal writing. (See off.) The adverb outside is not problematic when referring to physical space, position, etc. (I'm going outside), but the compound preposition outside of is often used as a colloquial (and often inferior) way of saying except for, other than, apart from (outside of what I just mentioned, I can't think of any reason not to). Besides possibly sounding more informal than desired, outside of may cause misunderstanding by suggesting physical space or location when that is not the point to be emphasized, or when no such sense is intended—consider the ambiguity in this sentence: outside of China, he has few interests. Does this mean that his primary interest is China? Or does it mean that whenever he is not in China, he has few interests?

definitions: the external side or surface of something

examples.text: record the date on the outside of the file

definitions: the side of a racetrack further from the center, where the lanes are longer.
shortDefinitions: part of path near to road

definitions: the side of a bend or curve where the edge or surface is longer in extent.
shortDefinitions: side of bend where edge is longer

definitions: (in basketball) the area beyond the perimeter of the defense

examples.text: he often set up the Lakers' plays from the outside

definitions: the external appearance of someone or something

examples.text: was he as straight as he appeared on the outside?

notes.text: Outside of tends to be more commonly used in the US than in Britain, where outside usually suffices, but, like its cousin off of, it is colloquial and not recommended for formal writing. (See off.) The adverb outside is not problematic when referring to physical space, position, etc. (I'm going outside), but the compound preposition outside of is often used as a colloquial (and often inferior) way of saying except for, other than, apart from (outside of what I just mentioned, I can't think of any reason not to). Besides possibly sounding more informal than desired, outside of may cause misunderstanding by suggesting physical space or location when that is not the point to be emphasized, or when no such sense is intended—consider the ambiguity in this sentence: outside of China, he has few interests. Does this mean that his primary interest is China? Or does it mean that whenever he is not in China, he has few interests?

definitions: situated on or near the exterior or external surface of something
(of a pitch) passing home plate on the side of the plate away from the batter, not in the strike zone.
shortDefinitions: (of pitch) passing home plate on side of plate away from batter

definitions: (in soccer and other sports) denoting positions nearer to the sides of the field
shortDefinitions: denoting positions nearer to sides of field

definitions: (in basketball) taking place beyond the perimeter of the defense

examples.text: he needs work on his outside shot

shortDefinitions: taking place beyond perimeter of defense

definitions: not belonging to or coming from within a particular group
beyond one's own immediate personal concerns

examples.text: I was able to face the outside world again
new monthly charges that, according to outside estimates, may total $8 per line

notes.text: Outside of tends to be more commonly used in the US than in Britain, where outside usually suffices, but, like its cousin off of, it is colloquial and not recommended for formal writing. (See off.) The adverb outside is not problematic when referring to physical space, position, etc. (I'm going outside), but the compound preposition outside of is often used as a colloquial (and often inferior) way of saying except for, other than, apart from (outside of what I just mentioned, I can't think of any reason not to). Besides possibly sounding more informal than desired, outside of may cause misunderstanding by suggesting physical space or location when that is not the point to be emphasized, or when no such sense is intended—consider the ambiguity in this sentence: outside of China, he has few interests. Does this mean that his primary interest is China? Or does it mean that whenever he is not in China, he has few interests?

definitions: situated or moving beyond the boundaries or confines of

examples.text: there was a boy outside the door

definitions: not being a member of (a particular group)

examples.text: those of us outside the university

definitions: (in football, soccer, and other sports) closer to the side of the field than (another player)

examples.text: Swift appeared outside him with Andrews on his left

shortDefinitions: closer to sides of field than

definitions: beyond the limits or scope of

examples.text: the high cost of shipping has put it outside their price range

notes.text: Outside of tends to be more commonly used in the US than in Britain, where outside usually suffices, but, like its cousin off of, it is colloquial and not recommended for formal writing. (See off.) The adverb outside is not problematic when referring to physical space, position, etc. (I'm going outside), but the compound preposition outside of is often used as a colloquial (and often inferior) way of saying except for, other than, apart from (outside of what I just mentioned, I can't think of any reason not to). Does this mean that his primary interest is China? Or does it mean that whenever he is not in China, he has few interests?

definitions: not within the boundaries or confines of a place

examples.text: the dog was still barking outside
outside, the wind was as wild as ever

definitions: moving so as to end up beyond the boundaries or confines of a place
shortDefinitions: moving so as to end up beyond boundaries of place
